legend.text: Note. Figures are in %. 2013 cohort: those in the KS4 Candidate/Indicator tables that belong to year group 11 (derived from birth date) and appear in the Census data (i.e. we have data on pre-determined characteristics). Students sitting English Language GCSE in the 2013 cohort are those students that are observed in the 2013 KS4 Results tables as having sat a full GCSE qualification in English Language with any of the awarding bodies. More details about the sample and data construction are given in Appendix A.

cell.text: AQA English Language C&D sample - Higher Tier
AQA English Language C&D sample - Foundation Tier
Not observed in education at age 18
Not observed in education, employment or training (NEET) at age 18
Enrolled in a level 3 qualification by age 19
Achieved a full level 3 qualification by age 19
Enrolled in any level 4+ qualification by age 19

statement.text: There are 8 different types of statistics in the given table.
The lowest value in the 2013 cohort sitting English Language GCSE is 8.3.
AQA English language sample has the smallest number of pupils.
The group Not observed in education at age 18 always has a smaller percentage than Not observed in education, employment or training(NEET) at age 18.
The group Enrolled in a level 3 qualification by age 18 is always higher than those that achieved a full level 3 qualification by age 19.
2013 cohort sitting English Language GCSE has the smallest value of 3.3.
The 2013 cohort sitting English language GCSE has the highest number of pupils.
The number of pupils exceeds 300,000 in at least one of the cohorts.
The highest percentage in the group not observed in education at age 18 is 14.2
The subsample of foundation students in the English Language sample with marks is in the C-D range
The patterns described when discussing predetermined characteristics for the same groups also emerge here

AQA English Language students (column 2) have slightly better outcomes than the average student in the cohort (column 1), and higher tier students perform much better than foundation students on any of the five dimensions analysed here.

legend.text: Note. NPD entries refer to the entries for AQA GCSE Full Courses found in the KS4 results dataset for academic year 2012-2013, summer season sittings.

cell.text: 2. Candidates with no discounted entries (and no duplicates)
3. Candidates with no inconsistency in grades across datasets
4. Candidates with data for all controls
a. Higher Tier all (of which C&D)
b. Foundation Tier all (of which C & D)

statement.text: Each Observation is unique
Foundation Tier all has the lowest valued Observation.
Candidates with data for all controls has the highest valued Observations.
Every Observation has a different value.
Candidates with data for all controls has the lowest valued Observations.
The last sample restriction is given by the availability of data to construct controls from the Student Census dataset, which is also part of the National Pupil Database.
This involves a bigger cut to the initial sample, and is explained by the fact that only students in state schools are included in the student census.

caption.text: Number of GCSE Full Course entries by Awarding Body (KS4 Results tables, 2014)

legend.text: Note. Number of GCSE Full Course entries in the summer season of the academic year 2012-2013. AQA (The Assessment and Qualifications Alliance); WJEC (Welsh Joint Education Committee); OCR (Oxford, Cambridge and RSA Examinations); CCEA (Council for the Curriculum, Examinations and Assessment). We do not show the information of an additional awarding body that accounts for almost no entries.

statement.text: The lowest total is 392015.
The highest Frequency, not counting the Total, is 84742.
AQA has the lowest percent for English Language.
The highest Percent value for OCR is 5.8
The highest total is 392015.
The highest percent is 55.7.
The highest English Percent is for AQA
The lowest Percent for OCR is 5.8

We also have access to information on who asked for a review on the different units of the GCSE English and GCSE English Language qualifications, and on the tier of the externally assessed unit (i.e. whether Foundation or Higher Tier).
This is for four main reasons.
First, this is due to technical problems in providing Unique Candidate Numbers (UPN) for all candidates.
